pages.title: ORSA Transponder
pages.text: The transponder is ORSA's last-resort emergency beacon. Once activated, it broadcasts a deep-space signal to any surviving relay satellites in orbit.$(br2)Building one requires the $(l:bold)ORSA Transponder Schematic$(/l) — a classified document found in ORSA wreckage. Without it, you won't even know what to build.$(br2)$(italic)"We hid the only escape plan in a random structure on a dying planet." — ORSA Security Division$(br)"That seems irresponsible." — Everyone else$(br)"We also hid the cafeteria key. We're not great at this." — ORSA Security Division$()

Requires 4 Refined Acheronite, 2 Diamond Blocks, a Thermal Core, a Frozen Heart, and a Frozen Atmosphere Shard. If this sounds expensive, remember what you're building: a phone call to space. Long distance rates apply.

pages.title: Activation Requirements
pages.text: $(li)$(bold)Depth:$() Must be placed below Y=0 to reach the deep relay network.$(br)$(li)$(bold)Power:$() A Geothermal Core must be within 12 blocks.$(br)$(li)$(bold)Sky Access:$() A clear vertical shaft from the transponder to the sky — no solid blocks. Yes, from bedrock to sky. Start digging.$(br)$(li)$(bold)Schematic:$() The ORSA Transponder Schematic must be archived first.$(br2)Once all conditions are met, right-click to activate. The broadcast takes approximately 100 minutes. We recommend a book and a warm beverage. You have neither. Sorry.

pages.title: During Broadcast
pages.text: A visible beam of light shoots upward through the shaft while broadcasting. The signal can be paused and resumed from the transponder's interface.$(br2)If conditions are lost during broadcast (core removed, shaft blocked), the transponder automatically pauses and plays a warning. It resumes when conditions are restored.$(br2)Snow is automatically cleared from the shaft by the signal energy. The beam vaporizes it. ORSA's most practical feature — designed entirely by accident.
